prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Correlator setup: We wish to obtain continuum data at 345 GHz with the largest possible bandwidth, and therefore propose for the default continuum setup for Band 7. Spectral resolution is not required for this continuum detection experiment.
Resolution: This is a detection experiment to determine flux densities of sources that are expected to have angular sizes of 1.5 arcsec or less. We do not require higher angular resolution as we do not need to map the emission regions. In fact, we will achieve the highest signal-to-noise (S/N) detections if the sources are unresolved, such that their emission falls into a single beam. With natural weighting of the data, observations using the most compact of the main array configurations (C34-1) will result in a resolution of about 1.5 arcsec, which is ideal for this project.
Sensitivity: If these targets are consistent with the FIR/radio correlation, we predict flux densities of at least 0.32 mJy. (This estimate varies slightly among our three science goals.) The requested sensitivity of 0.05 mJy/beam will result in S/N ratios of at least 6 in that case, with higher S/N for the brighter targets. The targets may be only 60% as bright as expected, and still consistent with the FIR/radio correlation. In that case, the sensitivity of 0.05 mJy/beam will result in S/N ratio of 4 on the faintest target. This S/N will still be sufficient to achieve our scientific goal, which requires determining whether or not the source flux densities are consistent with their predicted values based on the FIR/radio correlation.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to observe eight 0.2<z<0.3 radio-quiet quasi-stellar objects (QSOs) to determine if their radio emission is powered by luminous starbursts in their host galaxies or by active galactic nuclei (AGNs). Observations with the Jansky Very Large Array show that these QSOs, while considered ``radio-quiet", are far from radio silent. Rather, their radio emission is on par with that of local starburst galaxies: ~20 Msun/yr at z=0.25. With ALMA, we will determine whether these sources obey the tight far-infrared/radio correlation followed by nearly all star-forming galaxies. If so, the expected level of 345 GHz continuum emission is > 0.3 mJy, easily accessible with ALMA's high sensitivity. In contrast, if the AGN is the primary origin of radio emission, the targets will be ~100 times fainter at 345 GHz, resulting in non-detections. ALMA observations will thus efficiently determine whether host galaxies of luminous QSOs, which are known to be elliptical galaxies, also harbor luminous starbursts. Such starbursts are considered unusual for elliptical galaxies, but are an important component of AGN "feedback" models, in which starbursts are associated with rapid black-hole growth.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Astronomy and Space Science, Australia Telescope National Facility

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Astronomy, Washington, University of
Domenici Science Operations Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
